name: Real Estate
rationale: Massive market. Our new PostGIS data is a huge, unique advantage.

name: Government / Macro
rationale: Core to all users, but generating unique alpha is harder as the space is crowded.

name: Financials
rationale: Highly relevant audience. Powerful insights require new data (yield curve, stress indexes).

name: Industrials
rationale: Good for analyzing the 'real' economy. Can be correlated with supply chain data.

name: Consumer Discretionary
rationale: Relies heavily on consumer sentiment and retail sales. High potential if we add credit card data.

name: Energy
rationale: High alpha potential, but requires sourcing new, specific commodity price data (e.g., WTI).

name: Materials
rationale: Niche but potentially valuable. Requires new commodity price data (e.g., lumber, copper).

name: Information Technology
rationale: Analysis requires deep, company-specific data (EDGAR) or high-frequency data. High effort.

name: Communication Services
rationale: Very difficult to analyze with macro data alone. Relies on company-specific metrics. Low-priority.

name: Health Care
rationale: Highly specialized sector. Analysis requires domain expertise beyond macro data. Low-priority.

name: Utilities
rationale: Stable, regulated sector. Can be analyzed with interest rate and energy price data, but alpha is lower.

name: Consumer Staples
rationale: Defensive sector. Less sensitive to the macro trends we currently track. Low-priority.

name: The Core MVP: Affordability Ratio Over Time
rationale: The centerpiece of our analysis; answers a critical question for both cities. Requires sourcing comparable local HPI and Income data.

name: The "Rate-Lock" Effect (CAN vs. US)
rationale: Directly addresses a major current theme. Simple to build with existing national mortgage rate data and tells a powerful story about inventory.

name: Toronto vs. Chicago: Home Price Index Momentum
rationale: A direct, high-level comparison of market heat. Excellent top-line chart for a report. Requires sourcing the Canadian HPI.

name: Local GDP Growth vs. Home Price Appreciation
rationale: Shows the link between the 'real' economy and asset prices. A sophisticated insight. Requires local GDP data.

name: Construction Pipeline Pressure Index
rationale: Powerful leading indicator, but requires sourcing granular, comparable permit/housing start data for BOTH metros, which is difficult.

name: Housing Inventory Crisis Tracker
rationale: Visually powerful, but finding a consistent, reliable, and free source for active listings in both Toronto and Chicago is very hard.

name: Inflation Breakdown: Shelter vs. Other Goods
rationale: Isolates housing's contribution to inflation. Valuable, but requires finding specific CPI-Shelter series for both cities.

name: Mortgage Burden as a % of Income
rationale: A more nuanced affordability view, but requires complex assumptions about down payments and taxes, making it harder to implement quickly.
required_data_desc: HPI; Income; Mortgage Rates; Tax data

name: Credit Risk & Housing Downturn Map
rationale: Very high alpha, but near-impossible to get free, comparable, granular mortgage delinquency data for both countries.

name: New Housing Supply vs. Population Growth
rationale: Great insight, but reliable, high-frequency (annual) net migration data at the metro level is very difficult to source.

name: Sales Volume vs. New Listings
rationale: Classic indicator, but requires access to proprietary real estate board data feeds (TRREB, CAR), which are usually paid.

name: Delinquency Rate vs. Local Unemployment
rationale: Good leading indicator, but blocked by the difficulty of sourcing local delinquency data.

name: Impact of Central Bank Rate Hikes
rationale: Analysis is complex; requires careful handling of different mortgage term structures (US vs. CAN).

name: Office Vacancy Rates vs. Downtown Mobility
rationale: Excellent 'post-pandemic' insight, but requires paid Commercial Real Estate data (CBRE, etc.) and mobility data.

name: Priced Out": Net Migration vs. Affordability
rationale: Great narrative, but blocked by the difficulty of sourcing high-frequency migration data.

name: Single-Family vs. Multi-Family Trends
rationale: Interesting detail, but less impactful than the main affordability story. Requires finding permit data broken down by unit type.

name: Commercial vs. Residential Divergence
rationale: Requires sourcing paid Commercial Real Estate data, which is a major effort.

name: New Business Applications vs. Lease Rates
rationale: Interesting but niche. Blocked by need for CRE data and business application data for Toronto.

name: Local Unemployment vs. Transit Ridership
rationale: Interesting proxy for service sector health, but requires sourcing non-standard transit agency data for both cities.

name: Restaurant Spending vs. Consumer Confidence
rationale: Very powerful, but requires access to proprietary credit card transaction data, which is extremely expensive.
